verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:3
verses.text: Now this word "I am" expresses His eternal subsistence.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:4
verses.text: For if He is the reflection of the eternal light, He must also be eternal Himself.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:5
verses.text: For if the light subsists for ever, it is evident that the reflection also subsists for ever.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:6
verses.text: And that this light subsists, is known only by its shining; neither can there be a light that does not give light.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:7
verses.text: We come back, therefore, to our illustrations.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:8
verses.text: If there is day, there is light; and if there is no such thing, the sun certainly cannot be present.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:9
verses.text: If, therefore, the sun had been eternal, there would also have been endless day.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:10
verses.text: Now, however, as it is not so, the day begins when the sun rises, and it ends when the sun sets.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:11
verses.text: But God is eternal light, having neither beginning nor end.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:12
verses.text: And along with Him there is the reflection, also without beginning, and everlasting.

verses.name: Dionysius: On John VIII 1:13
verses.text: The Father, then, being eternal, the Son is also eternal, being light of light; and if God is the light, Christ is the reflection; and if God is also a Spirit, as it is written, "God is a Spirit," Christ, again, is called analogously Spirit.
